720905f-a.text:
Storage warehouses, Leroy Street, north side, from Washington to West Streets. Pier 4l, North River, is opposite the western end of Leroy Street.
July 15, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720905f-a.folder: Leroy Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724154f-b.text:
(1)
594-598 Washington Street, adjoining and at the S.W. corner of Leroy Street.
July 2S, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A close-up of the doorway of 596 Washington Street, an abandoned stable, shortly to be demolished along with the rest of the west side of the street.
July 25, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

724157f-a.text:
Washington Street, west side, north from Leroy Street.
July 25, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
724157f-a.folder: Washington Street & Leroy Street, Manhattan, NY

724159f-b.text:
Washington Street, east side, from Leroy (right) to Morton (left) Streets, as viewed northeastward from the clearance, where the elevated roadbed of the New York Central Railroad will be erected. The York Motor Express Co. occupy a 1 story garage (No. 599-601 Washington Street) at the N.E. corner of Leroy Street. Adjoining same is the 5 story building (No. 603-7) housing
the Stafford Ink Co.
A similar, tho narrower structure separates this from the 9 story building (No. 6l1-15) at the S.E. corner of Morton Street. The U. S. Medical Supply Department of the U. S. Army is given as the occupant of the latter.
View No. 1 is inclusive, showing all of these features; No's 2 and 3, various details.
December 3, 1931
Views 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr
View 1 - Neg.# 2628
724159f-b.folder: Washington Street & Leroy Street, Manhattan, NY

724156f-c.text:
(1)
Washington Street, south from and including Leroy Street.
JulY 16, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date, showing the elevated tracks of the New York Central Railroad and the new St. John's Park Freight Depot extending from Clarkson to Charlton Streets, after crossing West Houston and King Streets. The latter two streets pass underneath the building.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as View 2. Note the W.P.A. surface track removal program under operation.
April 28, 1937.
W.P.A. photo.
5 Boroughs Project.
